description: TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS H.J. RES. 240, THE RESOLUTION STATING CONGRESS' APPROVAL OF CERTAIN INTERNATIONAL FISHERY AGREEMENTS NEGOTIATED WITH FOREIGN COUNTRIES IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE FISHERY CONSERVATION MANAGEMENT ACT OF 1976.

TO AGREE TO H. RES. 252, A RESOLUTION DIRECTING THE COMMITTEE ON STANDARDS OF OFFICIAL  CONDUCT TO DETERMINE WHETHER MEMBERS OF THE HOUSE OR THEIR IMMEDIATE FAMILY OR ASSOCIATES HAVE ACCEPTED ANYTHING OF VALUE FROM THE SOUTH KOREAN GOVERNMENT OR ITS REPRESENTATIVES.

TO AGREE TO A SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT FOR THE SHUSTER AMENDMENT (SEE RC 29) TO H.R. 11.  THE  EDGAR AMENDMENT WOULD ALLOCATE 65% OF THE FUNDS TO ALL STATES BASED ON AVERAGE NUMBER OF UNEMPLOYED, AND 35% TO STATES WHOSE AVERAGE UNEMPLOYMENT RATE IS 6.5%+.
TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS H.R. 3753, THE BILL BRINGING CERTAIN GOVERNING INTERNATIONAL FISHERY AGREEMENTS WITHIN THE PURVIEW OF THE FISHERY CONSERVATION ZONE TRANSITION ACT.
TO AMEND H. RES. 287 BY STRIKING TITLE 3.  TITLE 3 CONTAINS LANGUAGE PROHIBITING THE MAINTENANCE OF UNOFFICIAL OFFICE ACCOUNTS TO DEFRAY CONGRESSIONAL OFFICE EXPENSES.

TO AMEND A COMMITTEE AMENDMENT TO H.R. 3839, THE BILL TO RESCIND CERTAIN BUDGET AUTHORITY  RECOMMENDED IN THE PRESIDENTIAL MESSAGE OF JAN. 17, 1977.  THE CHAPPELL AMENDMENT WOULD RESTORE $81.6 MILLION IN FUNDS FOR THE LONG-LEAD FUNDING OF A NIMITZ-CLASS NUCLEAR CARRIER.

TO AMEND A COMMITTEE AMENDMENT TO H.R. 3839 (SEE RC 42). THE BENNETT AMENDMENT WOULD RESTORE  $371 MILLION IN FUNDS FOR THE CONSTRUCTION OF AN AEGIS ANTI-AIRCRAFT SYSTEM ON BOARD THE NUCLEAR VESSEL THE USS LONG BEACH.

TO AGREE TO THE COMMITTEE AMENDMENT TO H.R. 3477 THAT WOULD PHASE OUT THE 1976 TAX REBATE  FOR PERSONS ANNUALLY EARNING $25,000+ AND WOULD GRANT $50 PAYMENTS TO RECIPIENTS OF BLACK LUNG BENEFITS, AID FOR DEPENDENT CHILDREN, AND VETERANS COMPENSATION.

TO RECOMMIT H.R. 3477 TO THE COMMITTEE ON WAYS AND MEANS WITH INSTRUCTIONS TO REPORT IT BACK WITH A SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT THAT WOULD REDUCE THE LOWER BRACKET TAX RATES FOR A TWO YEAR PERIOD RATHER THAN PROVIDE FOR $50 TAX REBATES.

TO RECOMMIT H. RES. 357, A RESOLUTION AUTHORIZING FUNDS FOR THE COMMITTEE ON THE JUDICIARY, TO THE COMMITTEE ON HOUSE ADMINISTRATION WITH INSTRUCTIONS TO REPORT IT BACK WITH A SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT THAT WOULD LIMIT FUNDS FOR INTERNAL SECURITY INVESTIGATIONS TO $300,000.

TO AGREE TO H. RES. 388, THE RULE TO CONSIDER H.R. 3843, A BILL AUTHORIZING ADDITIONAL FUNDS FOR LOW AND MODERATE INCOME HOUSING ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS, AND EXTENDING HUD RIOT AND CRIME INSURANCE PROGRAMS.  H.R. 3843 ALSO ESTABLISHES A NATIONAL COMMISSION ON NEIGHBORHOODS.

TO AMEND THE COMMITTEE AMENDMENT TO H.R. 1746, A BILL TO AMEND THE UNITED NATIONS PARTICIPATION  ACT OF 1945 SO AS TO HALT U.S. IMPORTATION OF RHODESIAN CHROME.  THE BAUMAN AMENDMENT PROHIBITS CHROME IMPORTS FROM ANY COUNTRY THAT HAS NOT COMPLIED WITH THE HUMAN RIGHTS PROVISIONS OF THE UNITED NATIONS CHARTER.

TO AMEND THE COMMITTEE AMENDMENT TO H.R. 1746 BY DELAYING FOR THIRTY DAYS THE EFFECTIVE  DATE OF THE BILL AND REQUIRING THAT THE PRESIDENT REPORT TO CONGRESS ON THE STATUS OF NEGOTIATIONS WITH THE RHODESIAN GOVERNMENT.

TO AGREE TO H. RES. 404, A RESOLUTION FOR THE IMMEDIATE COMMENCEMENT OF A 90 DAY TRIAL  PERIOD OF AUDIO COVERAGE OF DAILY HOUSE PROCEEDINGS.  THE RESOLUTION PROVIDES FOR A LATER EVALUATION OF THE TRIAL PERIOD BY THE HOUSE RULES COMMITTEE.

TO MODIFY AN AMENDMENT TO H.R. 4877 BY APPROPRIATING AN ADDITIONAL $200 MILLION  FOR THE EMERGENCY ENERGY-FUEL ASSISTANCE PROGRAM, PROVIDED THAT THE EXTRA FUNDS WILL NOT BE EXPENDED FOR ADMINISTRATIVE COSTS.

TO ORDER THE PREVIOUS QUESTION ON H. RES. 411, THE RULE TO CONSIDER H.R. 4800, A BILL EXTENDING THE EMERGENCY UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION ACT OF 1974 THROUGH MAR. 1978 AND REVISING ITS TRIGGER PROVISIONS.

TO AMEND THE SARASIN AMENDMENT OFFERED AS A SUBSTITUTE FOR THE QUIE AMENDMENT IN THE  NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE TO H.R. 4250.  THE ASHBROOK AMENDMENT LIMITS THE AUTHORITY OF A UNION TO INDUCE ANY PERSON TO STRIKE OR TO REFUSE TO WORK AT THE SITE OF A CONSTRUCTION, THEREBY PROTECTING FROM INVOLVEMENT THE EMPLOYER WHO IS NOT PRIMARILY INVOLVED IN THE CONSTRUCTION INDUSTRY.

TO AMEND THE SARASIN AMENDMENT OFFERED AS A SUBSTITUTE FOR THE QUIE AMENDMENT IN THE  NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE TO H.R. 4250.  THE QUIE AMENDMENT PROPOSES CONFINING SITUS PICKETING TO THE PROJECT WHERE THE LABOR DISPUTE ARISES, SO THAT ONLY THOSE EMPLOYERS WITH DIRECT CONTRACTUAL RELATIONSHIPS AS CONTRACTORS OR SUBCONTRACTORS CAN BE STRUCK.

TO AMEND THE SARASIN AMENDMENT OFFERED AS A SUBSTITUTE FOR THE QUIE AMENDMENT IN THE  NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE TO H.R. 4250.  THIS AMENDMENT EXEMPTS FROM THE DEFINITION OF "SITE" THOSE SITES RAISING RESIDENTIAL BUILDINGS OF THREE STORIES OR LESS.

TO AMEND THE SARASIN AMENDMENT OFFERED AS A SUBSTITUTE FOR THE QUIE AMENDMENT IN THE  NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE TO H.R. 4250.  THE EDWARDS AMENDMENT WOULD REQUIRE A VOTE  OF APPROVAL BY SECRET BALLOT BY THE AFFECTED WORKERS IN ORDER TO AUTHORIZE UNION COMMON SITUS ACTION.

TO AGREE TO THE MODIFIED SARASIN AMENDMENT OFFERED AS A SUBSTITUTE FOR THE QUIE  AMENDMENT IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE FOR H.R. 4250.  THE MODIFIED SARASIN AMENDMENT CONTAINS THE MAJOR LANGUAGE OF H.R. 5900, A PIECE OF PICKETING LEGISLATION THAT WAS VETOED BY THE 94TH CONGRESS. H.R. 4250.

TO PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 3965, A BILL AUTHORIZING $85 MILLION TO THE FEDERAL  AVIATION ADMINISTRATION (FAA) FOR FISCAL YEAR 1978.  THE APPROPRIATED MONIES ARE FOR RESEARCH, DEVELOPMENT AND DEMONSTRATION PROJECTS RELATED TO AVIATION.

TO PASS H. RES. 420, A BILL TO ESTABLISH A SELECT COMMITTEE ON CONGRESSIONAL  OPERATIONS WHICH SHALL BE COMPOSED OF SEVEN MEMBERS OF THE HOUSE AND SHALL REPLACE THE JOINT COMMITTEE ON CONGRESSIONAL OPERATIONS.

TO AGREE TO AN AMENDMENT IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE TO THE COMMITTEE AMENDMENTS  TO H.R. 5045, THE REORGANIZATION ACT OF 1977.  THE WALKER AMENDMENT OFFERS A REORGANIZATION  FORMAT THAT WOULD REQUIRE THAT CONGRESS VOTE ON REORGANIZATION PLANS SUBMITTED BY THE PRESIDENT, RATHER THAN LETTING THE PLANS TAKE EFFECT UNLESS DISAPPROVED BY EITHER HOUSE WITHIN 60 DAYS OF THEIR SUBMISSION.

TO AGREE TO SECTION 2 OF THE COMMITTEE AMENDMENTS TO H. RES. 393.  SECTION 2 AUTHORIZES  ADDITIONAL FUNDS FOR OFFICE PERSONNEL AND THE LEASING OF EQUIPMENT FOR MAJORITY AND MINORITY LEADERS, AND MAJORITY AND MINORITY WHIPS.

TO AGREE TO THE COMMITTEE AMENDMENTS TO H.R. 4976, A BILL AMENDING SEVERAL PUBLIC SERVICE ACTS.  THE PROPOSED AMENDMENTS INCREASE AUTHORIZATIONS FOR DEMONSTRATION PROJECTS FOR HOME HEALTH SERVICES FROM $4.45 MILLION TO $12 MILLION.

TO PASS H.R. 4976, A BILL THAT AMENDS THE PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE ACT, THE COMMUNITY  MENTAL HEALTH CENTERS ACT AND TITLE 5 OF THE SOCIAL SECURITY ACT AND APPROPRIATES $1.1 BILLION IN FUNDS FOR 1978 HEALTH SERVICES PROGRAMS.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS H.R. 3695, A BILL IMPROVING THE PRESENT PROGRAM FOR ALLOCATING GRANT MONIES TO STATES FOR THE CONSTRUCTION AND RENOVATION OF MEDICAL FACILITIES SERVING ELIGIBLE VETERANS.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 1828, A BILL PROVIDING THAT THE CHANGES MADE BY THE TAX REFORM ACT OF 1976, IN PARTICULAR THE EXCLUSION FOR SICK PAY FOR ALL BUT TOTALLY DISABLED AND RETIRED TAXPAYERS, BE APPLICABLE AS OF JAN. 1, 1977.
TO AGREE TO H. RES. 469, THE RULE TO CONSIDER H.R. 5294, A BILL TO AMEND THE  CONSUMER CREDIT PROTECTION ACT AND PROVIDE PROTECTION FROM CERTAIN ABUSIVE TACTICS OF DEBT COLLECTOR AGENCIES.
TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 5717, A BILL TO PROVIDE $20 MILLION IN ASSISTANCE AND REHABILITATION FUNDS TO THE VICTIMS OF THE RECENT EARTHQUAKE DISASTERS IN RUMANIA.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 7, A BILL AUTHORIZING $275 MILLION  FOR FISCAL YEARS 1978-1985 FOR LOCAL AND STATE CAREER EDUCATION PROGRAMS DESIGNED FOR STUDENTS AT THE ELEMENTARY AND SECONDARY SCHOOL LEVELS.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 130, A BILL PROTECTING FRANCHISED  DISTRIBUTORS AND RETAILERS OF MOTOR FUEL, UPHOLDING COMPETITION IN THE GASOLINE MARKET AND YET ENCOURAGING CONSERVATION OF FUEL BY REQUIRING THE DISCLOSURE TO CUSTOMERS OF OCTANE RATINGS OF ALL TYPES OF AUTO GASOLINE.
TO  AMEND H.R. 5262 BY DIRECTING U.S. OFFICIALS IN INTERNATIONAL LENDING  INSTITUTIONS TO OPPOSE FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE FOR AGRICULTURAL PROJECTS PROMOTING SUGAR, PALM OIL, OR CITRUS CROPS.
TO AMEND H.R. 5262 BY PROHIBITING THAT INTERNATIONAL LENDING INSTITUTIONS USE  U.S. FUNDS FOR FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO CAMBODIA, CUBA, LAOS, AND VIETNAM.
TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS H.R. 3340, AS AMENDED.  H.R. 3340 AMENDS THE INTERNAL REVENUE CODE OF 1954 SO AS TO ALLOW BUSINESS TAX CREDITS FOR BUSINESSES OR RESIDENCES THAT OFFER DAY CARE SERVICES.
TO PASS H.R. 5101, THE BILL AUTHORIZING OF $313 MILLION FOR RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT OF THE  ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY FOR FISCAL YEAR 1978.

TO PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 5840, EXPORT ADMINISTRATION AMENDMENTS OF 1977.  THIS BILL REVISES  U.S. CONTROLS ON THE EXPORTATION OF CERTAIN SENSITIVE MATERIALS, AND PROHIBITS THAT U.S. FIRMS COMPLY COMPLETELY WITH THE ARAB BOYCOTT OF ISRAELI GOODS.
THAT THE HOUSE RECEDE AND CONCUR IN A SENATE AMENDMENT TO H.R. 4877 THAT WOULD AUTHORIZE FUNDS OF  $1.17 MILLION FOR THE UNIFORMED SERVICES UNIVERSITY OF THE HEALTH SCIENCES.

TO REJECT A PREFERENTIAL MOTION TO CONCUR IN SENATE AMENDMENT #35 TO H.R. 4877 AND EXPRESS THE  SENSE OF THE HOUSE THAT SAID AMENDMENT SHOULD NOT STAND.  SENATE AMENDMENT #35 DEALS WITH THE AUTHORIZATION OF AN ADDITIONAL $20 MILLION TO REIMBURSE STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS FOR THE HIGH COSTS OF SNOW REMOVAL DURING THE WINTER OF 1976-1977.

TO AMEND H.R. 5970, A BILL AUTHORIZING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE FOR FISCAL 1978, BY PROHIBITING THE PURCHASE OF THREE AIRBORNE WARNING AND CONTROL SYSTEM AIRCRAFTS (AWACS) UNLESS THAT PURCHASE IS AGREED TO BY NATO.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS H.R. 5675, A BILL ALLOWING THE SECRETARY OF THE TREASURY TO TRANSFER CERTAIN SURPLUS CASH FUNDS CURRENTLY KEPT IN INTEREST-FREE "TAX AND LOAN ACCOUNTS" IN DEPOSITORY INSTITUTIONS.

TO AMEND H.R. 5970, A BILL AUTHORIZING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE FOR FISCAL 1978, BY REDUCING THE PRESENT OVERSEAS TROOP STRENGTH BY 17,000 AND BY REDUCING THE PROJECTED END-STRENGTH TROOP LEVEL BY 50,000.
TO AMEND H.R. 5970 BY PROVIDING THAT IN THE FUTURE ALL MEMBERS OF THE MILITARY WILL BE PLACED UNDER THE CONGRESSIONAL PENSION SYSTEM.

THAT THE TREEN AMENDMENT TO H.R. 5970, AN AMENDMENT APPROVED BY VOICE VOTE IN THE COMMITTEE OF THE  WHOLE, BE SUBJECT TO A RECORDED VOTE.  THE TREEN AMENDMENT PROHIBITS THE EXPENDITURE OF FUNDS TO ADVERTISE THE PRESENT ADMINISTRATION'S REVIEW PROGRAM FOR VIETNAM-ERA DESERTERS.
TO AMEND H. CON. RES. 195 BY REDUCING BUDGET AUTHORITY AND OUTLAYS IN THE GENERAL GOVERNMENT FUNCTIONS BY $7 MILLION IN ORDER TO ELIMINATE THE PROPOSED 29% PAY RAISE FOR MEMBERS OF CONGRESS.
TO AMEND THE SECOND PIKE AMENDMENT TO H. CON. RES. 195 BY CUTTING THE NATIONAL DEFENSE FUNDS  BY $7.95 BILLION AND USING THOSE FUNDS TO REDUCE THE NATIONAL DEBT.

TO ADOPT A SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT TO THE SECOND PIKE AMENDMENT TO H. CON. RES. 195.  THE  BURLESON AMENDMENT INCREASES DEFENSE SPENDING BY $4.1 BILLION AND OUTLAYS BY $2.3 BILLION SO AS TO REACH THE SPENDING LEVELS RECOMMENDED BY THE PRESIDENT.

TO ADOPT THE AMENDED PIKE AMENDMENT (SEE RC 156 AND 157) TO H. CON. RES. 195.  THE ORIGINAL  VERSION OF THIS SECOND PIKE AMENDMENT WOULD HAVE CUT BUDGET AUTHORITY BY $130 MILLION IN ORDER TO ELIMINATE THE 29% PROPOSED PAY RAISE FOR THE FEDERAL JUDICIARY, THE EXECUTIVE BRANCH, AND CERTAIN OTHER FEDERAL EMPLOYEES.

TO OFFER AN AMENDMENT IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE TO THE COMMITTEE AMENDMENT TO H. CON. RES. 195.   THE MITCHELL AMENDMENT TRANSFERS $6.5 BILLION IN BUDGET AUTHORITY AND $3.6 BILLION IN OUITLAYS FROM DEFENSE PROGRAMS TO DOMESTIC PROGRAMS.
TO AMEND H. CON. RES. 195 BY INCREASING BUDGET AUTHORITY AND OUTLAYS BY $500 MILLION EACH FOR  PENSION PROGRAMS OF WORLD WAR I VETERANS.

TO OFFER AN AMENDMENT IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE TO A COMMITTEE AMENDMENT TO H.  CON. RES. 195.  THE LATTA AMENDMENT PROVIDES FOR REDUCED OUTLAYS, A REDUCED DEFICIT AND A PERMANENT "ACROSS-THE-BOARD" TAX REDUCTION.

TO OFFER AN AMENDMENT IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE TO A COMMITTEE AMENDMENT TO H. CON. RES. 195.  THE ROUSSELOT AMENDMENT WOULD PROVIDE FOR 1978 REVENUES OF $409 BILLION, BUDGET AUTHORITY OF $453.5 BILLION, OUTLAYS OF $409 BILLION, AND NO DEFICIT.
TO PASS H. CON. RES. 195.  THE MODIFIED BILL PROVIDES FOR REVENUES OF $398.1  BILLION, BUDGET AUTHORITY OF $505.7 BILLION, OUTLAYS OF $466.7 BILLION AND A DEFICIT OF $68.6 BILLION IN FISCAL 1978.

TO AGREE TO THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON H.R. 3843, THE SUPPLEMENTAL HOUSING AUTHORIZATIONS FOR FISCAL  1977.  THE FINAL VERSION OF THE BILL AUTHORIZES AN ADDITIONAL $378 MILLION IN FISCAL YEAR 1977 FOR LOW AND MODERATE INCOME HOUSING ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS.
TO PASS, AS AMENDED, H. RES. 465, A RESOLUTION AUTHORIZING $2.5 MILLION FOR THE CONTINUED  INVESTIGATIONS OF THE HOUSE SELECT COMMITTEE ON ASSASSINATIONS.
TO PASS H. RES. 523, THE RULE TO CONSIDER H.R. 2, A BILL TO PROVIDE FOR THE REGULATION OF SURFACE COAL MINING OPERATIONS.
THAT THE HOUSE RESOLVE ITSELF INTO THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE FOR FURTHER CONSIDERATION  OF H.R. 2,  STRIP MINING CONTROL AND RECLAMATION ACT OF 1977.

TO AMEND H.R. 2  BY PROHIBITING SURFACE MINING IN ALLUVIAL VALLEYS WEST OF THE 100TH MERIDIAN  WITH THE EXCEPTION OF THOSE OPERATIONS ISSUED PERMITS BEFORE JAN. 4, 1977 AND WITH THE FURTHER EXCEPTION OF THOSE OPERATIONS ENGAGED IN COMMERCIAL PRODUCTION ONE YEAR PRIOR TO THE ENACTMENT OF THE BILL.

TO SET ASIDE $300 MILLION IN OUTER CONTINENTAL SHELF LEASING RECEIPTS FOR THE FUNDING OF A  PROGRAM FOR THE RECLAMATION OF ABANDONED MINES.  SUCH ACTION WOULD TAKE PLACE BEFORE THE LEVYING OF RECLAMATION FEES ON MINED COAL.
TO RECOMMIT H.R. 2 TO THE AD HOC COMMITTEE ON ENERGY WITH INSTRUCTIONS TO RECONSIDER  THE BILL IN THE LIGHT OF THE PRESIDENT'S ENERGY MESSAGE OF APR. 20, 1977.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 6550.  H.R. 6550 AUTHORIZES APPROPRIATIONS TO CERTAIN TERRITORIES OF THE UNITED STATES, INCLUDING THE TRUST TERRITORY OF THE PACIFIC ISLANDS AND THE NORTHERN MARIANA ISLANDS, AND THE TERRITORY OF GUAM.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 4390, A BILL AUTHORIZING $31.05 MILLION IN FISCAL  YEAR 1978 FOR THE CONSTRUCTION OF THE DAM AND CANAL, THE SAN LUIS UNIT, CENTRAL VALLEY PROJECT, CALIFORNIA.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, S. 36, A BILL TO AUTHORIZE $4.9 BILLION IN FISCAL  YEAR 1977 TO THE ENERGY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT ADMINISTRATION FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF CERTAIN NON-NUCLEAR RESEARCH PROJECTS.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS H.R. 5025, A BILL TO AMEND TITLE 38 OF THE UNITED STATES CODE SO THAT  THE CONSTRUCTION OF ANY VETERANS ADMINISTRATION MEDICAL FACILITY COSTING MORE THAN $1 MILLION SHALL BE SUBJECT TO THE APPROVAL OF THE HOUSE AND THE SENATE VETERANS' AFFAIRS COMMITTEES.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 4007, A BILL REVISING THE INTERNAL REVENUE CODE  OF 1954 SO THAT THE DISTRICT THAT A STATE LEGISLATOR REPRESENTS WILL BE DESIGNATED HIS HOME.  H.R. 4007 IS DESIGNED TO FACILITATE THE FIGURING OF TRAVEL EXPENSE DEDUCTIONS FOR STATE LEGISLATORS.
TO AGREE TO H. RES. 489, A RESOLUTION PROVIDING FUNDS FOR THE INVESTIGATIONS CONDUCTED  BY THE HOUSE SELECT COMMITTEE ON CONGRESSIONAL OPERATIONS.

TO STRIKE TITLE II OF THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON H.R. 11, A BILL PROVIDING FOR A PROGRAM OF PUBLIC WORKS JOBS.  TITLE II OF THE REPORT DIRECTS THE PRESIDENT TO SPEND SOME OF THE FUNDS PREVIOUSLY APPROPRIATED FOR CERTAIN WATER PROJECTS IN THE U.S.
TO AMEND H.R. 6179 BY REQUIRING THAT THE ARMS CONTROL AND DISARMAMENT AGENCY REPORT TO CONGRESS  ON THE PROSPECTS FOR VERIFICATION OF THE PROPOSED ARMS CONTROL AGREEMENTS.

TO AMEND H.R. 6689 BY REDUCING THE U.S. CONTRIBUTION TO THE UNITED NATIONS FROM $218 MILLION TO $57.6 MILLION.  THE CRANE AMENDMENT IS DESIGNED TO LIMIT THE U.S. CONTRIBUTION TO A PERCENTAGE NO GREATER THAN THE RATIO OF THE U.S. POPULATION TO THE TOTAL POPULATION OF ALL OTHER UNITED NATIONS' MEMBERS.
TO AGREE TO A SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT TO THE DORNAN AMENDMENT TO H.R. 6689.  THE BUCHANAN  AMENDMENT REQUIRES THAT ANY NEW PANAMA CANAL TREATY MUST PROTECT THE VITAL INTERESTS OF THE UNITED STATES.

TO AMEND THE MITCHELL, MD. AMENDMENT TO H. CON. RES. 214, THE FIRST CONCURRENT RESOLUTION ON  THE BUDGET FOR FISCAL 1978, BY INCREASING THE DEFENSE BUDGET AUTHORITY BY $3 BILLION AND OUTLAYS BY $2 BILLION.

TO AGREE TO AN AMENDMENT IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE TO H. CON. RES. 214.  THE CONABLE AMENDMENT WOULD PROVIDE FOR REDUCED OUTLAYS, A REDUCED DEFICIT, INCREASED FUNDING FOR DEFENSE, AN  ACROSS-THE-BOARD PERSONAL TAX DEDUCTION AND ELIMINATION OF THE BUSINESS TAX CREDIT.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 6668.  THIS BILL EXTENDS FOR SIX MONTHS THE  DATE UPON WHICH THE UNITED STATES COMMISSION ON CIVIL RIGHTS MUST FILE ITS REPORT ON AGE DISCRIMINATION AND ALSO EXTENDS THE COMMODITIES PROVISION OF THE OLDER AMERICANS ACT OF 1965.

TO AGREE TO H. RES. 334, THE RESOLUTION APPROVING THE CONTINUED APPOINTMENT  OF A SPECIAL COUNSEL TO REPRESENT THE HOUSE AND THE COMMITTEE ON INTERSTATE AND FOREIGN COMMERCE IN THE PENDING COURT CASE REGARDING A POSSIBLE TELEPHONE WIRETAP BY AT AND T.

TO INSTRUCT THE HOUSE CONFEREES APPOINTED TO JOINTLY CONSI- DER H.R. 5840, THE BILL TO AMEND THE EXPORT ADMINISTRATION ACT OF 1969, THAT THEY INSIST ON THE LANGUAGE IN SECTION 110 OF THE HOUSE BILL.  SECTION 110 PROHIBITS THE EXPORTATION OF ALASKAN OIL FOR THE NEXT TWO YEARS.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 6206, A BILL AUTHORIZING APPROPRIATIONS FOR  FISCAL YEARS 1978-1980 FOR THE EFFECTIVE ENACTMENT OF THE COMMERCIAL FISHERIES RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT ACT OF 1964.
TO AMEND H.R. 6655, HOUSING AND COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT ACT OF 1977, BY STRIKING THE  PROPOSED FORMULA FOR ALLOCATION OF COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT BLOCK GRANTS AND RESTATING THE FORMULA OTHERWISE.

TO AMEND H.R. 6655 BY REQUIRING THAT LENDING INSTITUTIONS THAT OFFER FLOOD RELIEF PLANS  MUST MAKE CLEAR THAT IF THEIR PLAN IS PURCHASED, THE COMMUNITY IS NO LONGER ELIGIBLE FOR FEDERAL FLOOD DISASTER RELIEF.

TO AMEND H.R. 6714 BY REDUCING BY $25.75 MILLION THE U.S. VOLUNTARY CONTRIBUTION  TO INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS FOR FISCAL 1978.  THE REDUCTION RETURNS THE TOTAL TO THE FIGURE REQUESTED BY THE PRESIDENT.
TO AMEND H.R. 6810 BY CHANGING THE FORMULA FOR THE DISTRIBUTION OF THE APPROPRIATED  FUNDS TO A FORMULA BASED ON STATE AND LOCAL TAX EFFORT INSTEAD OF ON STATE AND LOCAL UNEMPLOYMENT.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 3849, A BILL SPECIFYING QUALIFICATIONS  FOR MEMBERSHIP TO THE NATIONAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON OCEANS AND ATMOSPHERE, AND AUTHORIZING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THAT COMMITTEE.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 4746, A BILL EXTENDING THE AUTHORITY  OF THE SECRETARY OF THE INTERIOR WITH RESPECT TO RESEARCH PROJECTS ON WATER RESOURCES AND SALINE WATER CONVERSION.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 5885, THE BILL AUTHORIZING  FURTHER APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE CONTINUED CONSTRUCTION OF CERTAIN FLOOD CONTROL PROJECTS IN 18 RIVER BASINS OF THE UNITED STATES.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 2501, A BILL TO AMEND  CERTAIN PUBLIC SURVEY RECORDS SO AS TO ELIMINATE A CONFLICT OF PROPERTY TITLES FOR THE SO-CALLED WOLD TRACT IN THE MEDICINE BOW NATIONAL FOREST IN WYOMING.
TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS, AS AMENDED, H.R. 6010, A BILL TO AMEND THE FEDERAL AVIATION  ACT OF 1958 WITH RESPECT TO TYPES OF RISK THAT MAY BE INSURED OR REINSURED.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS  S. 1279, THE SENATE BILL TO TEMPORARILY PROVIDE THE  SECRETARY OF COMMERCE WITH THE AUTHORITY TO FACILITATE EMERGENCY ACTIONS NECESSITATED BY THE 1976-1977 U.S. DROUGHT.

TO CONCUR IN THE SENATE AMENDMENT TO THE HOUSE AMENDMENT TO THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON  S. CON. RES. 19, THE SENATE BILL SETTING BUDGET TARGETS FOR 1978.  THE MODIFIED CONFERENCE REPORT SETS REVENUE LEVELS AT $393.6 BILLION, BUDGET AUTHORITY OF $503.45 BILLION, OUTLAYS OF $460.95 BILLION AND A DEFICIT OF $64.65 BILLION.

TO AMEND H.R. 1139 BY LIMITING THE NUMBER OF PARTICIPANTS IN THE SUMMER FOOD PROGRAM IN ANY ONE  STATE TO NO MORE THAN TWICE THE NUMBER OF SCHOOL AGE CHILDREN FROM POVERTY-LEVEL FAMILIES IN THE STATE.

TO AMEND H.R. 1139 BY LIMITING THE NUMBER OF PARTICIPANTS IN THE SUMMER FOOD PROGRAM TO THE  AVERAGE OF THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN IN THAT AREA THAT ARE ELIGIBLE FOR FREE OR REDUCED PRICE MEALS DURING THE SCHOOL YEAR.

TO AMEND H.R. 1139 BY PROVIDING THE OPTION TO RECEIVE CASH INSTEAD OF THE COMMODITIES NORMALLY  SUPPLIED UNDER THE ACT.  THE GOODLING AMENDMENT WOULD PERMIT EACH LOCAL SCHOOL DISTRICT THE CHOICE OF THE TWO OPTIONS.
TO AMEND H.R. 10 BY PERMITTING THAT FEDERAL EMPLOYEES MAY PARTICIPATE IN POLITICAL ACTIVITY  AND VOTING AT STATE AND LOCAL LEVELS, BUT NOT AT FEDERAL LEVELS.
Issue1: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO AMEND H.R. 10 BY PROHIBITING THAT ANY EMPLOYEE ORGANIZATION MAY DIRECTLY OR INDIRECTLY  INTIMIDATE, THREATEN, OR COERCE FEDERAL EMPLOYEES TO VOTE FOR A CERTAIN CANDIDATE OR A CERTAIN MEASURE.
Issue1: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO AMEND H.R. 10 BY DELETING LANGUAGE IN THE BILL THAT CLASSIFIES THE EXTORTION OF POLITICAL CONTRIBUTIONS FROM FEDERAL PERSONNEL AS A CRIMINAL OFFENSE.
Issue1: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS S. 1443 IN LIEU OF H.R. 6258. THE EFFECT OF S. 1443 IS  TO EXTEND UNTIL SEPT. 30, 1977 THE AUTHORIZATIONS FOR THE PRIVACY PROTECTION STUDY COMMISSION.
TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS H.R. 1862, THE BILL TO AMEND TITLE 38 OF THE UNITED STATES  CODE AND INCREASE BY APPROXIMATELY 60% THE DISABILITY COMPENSATION RATES FOR DISABLED VETERANS.

TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS H.R. 6501, A BILL AMENDING TITLE 38 OF THE UNITED STATES  CODE SO AS TO INCREASE THE DISABILITY COMPENSATION FOR THOSE VETERANS DISABLED BY THE LOSS OR LOSS OF USE OF PAIRED EXTREMITIES.
TO SUSPEND THE RULES AND PASS H.R. 6502, A BILL AMENDING TITLE 38 OF THE UNITED STATES  CODE BY PROVIDING AN ALLOWANCE FOR AUTOMOTIVE ADAPTIVE EQUIPMENT FOR DISABLED VETERANS OF WORLD WAR I.

TO MODIFY THE FASCELL AMENDMENT TO H.R. 12514, THE BILL AUTHORIZING APPROPRIATIONS FOR INTERNAITONAL SECURITY ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS FOR FISCAL YEAR 1979.  THE MODIFIED FASCELL AMENDMENT WILL LIFT THE U.S. ARMS EMBARGO AGAINST TURKEY UPON THE PRESIDENT'S CERTIFICATION TO CONGRESS THAT IT IS IN THE INTEREST OF THE U.S. AND N.A.T.O. TO DO SO, AND THAT "TURKEY IS ACTING IN GOOD FAITH TO ACHIEVE A JUST AND PEACEFUL SETTLEMENT OF THE CYPRUS PROBLEM."  THE ORIGINAL FASCELL AMENDMENT WOULD HAVE LIFTED THE ARMS EMBARGO FOR A PERIOD OF ONE YEAR AS SOON AS TURKEY REMOVED ITS TROOPS FROM FAMAGUSTA, AND AS SOON AS THE UNITED NATIONS TOOK OVER THE ADMINISTRATION OF SAID CITY, AND TALKS AIMED AT SETTLEMENT OF THE CYPRUS PROBLEM WERE RESUMED.

TO AGREE TO AN AMENDMENT OFFERED IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE FOR THE STRATTON AMENDMENT TO H.R. 12514.  THE MODIFIED STRATTON AMENDMENT EXPRESSES THE SENSE OF CONGRESS THAT FURTHER WITHDRAWAL OF U.S. TROOPS FROM SOUTH KOREA "MAY SERIOUSLY RISK UPSETTING THE MILITARY BALANCE IN THAT REGION AND REQUIRES FULL ADVANCE CONSULTATION WITH THE CONGRESS."  THE ORIGINAL STRATTON AMENDMENT WOULD HAVE DRASTICALLY REDUCED THE AUTHORIZATION FOR THE TRANSFER OF U.S. MILITARY EQUIPMENT TO SOUTH KOREA, A TRANSFER WITHOUT REIMBURSEMENT THAT WAS CONNECTED TO THE WITHDRAWAL OF NOT MORE THAN 6,000 U.S. TROOPS.

TO MODIFY THE ZABLOCKI AMENDMENT OFFERED IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE FOR THE BAUMAN AMENDMENT TO H.R. 12514.  THE FINDLEY MODIFYING AMENDMENT IMMEDIATELY LIFTS U.S. ECONOMIC SANCTIONS AGAINST RHODESIA UNLESS THE PRESIDENT DETERMINES THAT THE GOVERNMENT OF RHODESIA HAS "REFUSED" TO PARTICIPATE AND NEGOTIATE IN GOOD FAITH AT AN ALL-PARTIES CONFERENCE TO DISCUSS RELEVENT ISSUES, OR IF THE PRESIDENT DETERMINES THAT THE RHODESIAN GOVERNMENT "FAILED TO SCHEDULE" FREE ELECTIONS.  THE ZABLOCKI SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT LIFTS U.S. SANCTIONS AGAINST RHODESIA AS SOON AS THE PRESIDENT DETERMINES THAT THE SOUTH RHODESIAN GOVERNMENT HAS COMMITTED ITSELF TO PARTICIPATE IN AND NEGOTIATE IN GOOD FAITH IN AN ALL-PARTIES CONFERENCE, AND AS SOON AS A NEW RHODESIAN GOVERNMENT, CHOSEN BY FREE ELECTION, HAS BEEN INSTALLED.  THE ORIGINAL BAUMAN AMENDMENT BANS U.S. ECONOMIC SANCTIONS AGAINST RHODESIA BEFORE OCT. 1, 1979 UNLESS THE RHODESIAN GOVERNMENT "HAS NOT COMMITTED ITSELF" TO AN ALL-PARTIES CONFERENCE OR HAS "MADE NO DEFINITE PLANS" FOR FREE ELECTIONS.

TO MODIFY THE ZABLOCKI SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT FOR THE BAUMAN AMENDMENT (SEE RC 634) TO H.R. 12514.  THE ICHORD MODIFYING AMENDMENT BANS U.S. SANCTIONS AGAINST RHODESIA AFTER DEC. 31, 1978 UNLESS THE PRESIDENT DETERMINES THAT A NEW RHODESIAN GOVERNMENT HAS NOT BEEN INSTALLED NOR ELECTED BY FREE ELECTIONS IN WHICH ALL POLITICAL GROUPS HAVE BEEN FREE TO PARTICIPATE.

TO AMEND H.R. 12931 BY PROHIBITING USE OF THESE FUNDS FOR DIRECT OR INDIRECT AID TO VIETNAM, CAMBODIA, LAOS, AND UGANDA.

TO AMEND H.R. 13635 BY INCREASING THE APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE INCENTIVE PROGRAMS FOR THE DIFFERENT BRANCHES OF THE RESERVE AND OF THE NATIONAL GUARD.

TO AMEND H.R. 13635 BY PROHIBITING USE OF THESE FUNDS FOR PROCUREMENT OF TACTICAL SUPPORT OR OF TRACKED OR NON-TRACKED VEHICLES MANUFACTURED OUTSIDE OF THE UNITED STATES, EXCEPT FOR TEST AND EVALUATION PURPOSES.
